conclusion: To determine when the two objects are farthest apart, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph.
The distance traveled by each object can be found by calculating the area under the velocity-time graph.
The velocity-time graph shows the velocity of objects A and B as a function of time.
The area under the velocity-time graph gives the distance traveled by each object.
For object A, the velocity decreases from v0 to 0 over time t4.
The area under the graph for object A is a triangle.
For object B, the velocity increases from 0 to v0 and then decreases back to 0 over time t4.
The area under the graph for object B is also a triangle.
The farthest apart the two objects will be is when the difference in the areas under their velocity-time graphs is maximized.
From the graph, we can see that the areas under the graphs are equal at t2 and t3.
We need to find the exact moment when the distance is maximized.
The graphs intersect at t2 and t3.
At these points, the distances traveled by both objects are the same, so they are not farthest apart.
The farthest apart will be just before or after the intersection points where the difference in the areas is maximized.

By observing the graph, the farthest apart the objects will be is at t3, where the area under the graph for object A is greater than the area under the graph for object B, and the difference is maximized.
